course_title: Writing the Genre Novel: Heroes, Lovers, and Monsters

learning_outcomes.description: Conceptualise genre as it relates to fiction and to the literary marketplace.
Develop critical analysis skills and apply them to creative practice.
Demonstrate writing fluency and time management skills essential for creative writing practice, including planning, researching, drafting, and revising under deadline constraints.

assessments.category: Notebook/ Logbook, Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Across the semester, you will use a template to complete 8 short in-class written reflections, one in each tutorial. You will receive a different weekly prompt during each tutorial. Your best 6 scores will be counted toward your final grade. The logbooks will ask you to reflect on what you learned in the lecture, tutorial, peer workshops and/or in your own reading for that week's topic ie characterisation, plotting, building tension.

Purpose

These reflections help you:

  • Consolidate what you learned in that week’s lecture, tutorial and peer workshopping sessions.
  • Demonstrate the changes or adjustments you made to your practice or thinking
  • Build employability skills in rapid analysis, critical thinking, insight generation, concise writing and academic reflection


Format:

  • Handwritten in class
  • Template provided
  • Tutorial prompt given on the day
  • You will have 20 minutes for each reflection
  • Approx. 200-300 words in total


Note:

  • Each weekly response is marked out of 5%
  • 6 highest-scoring reflections contribute to the final 30%
  • Marking focuses on:
  • Insight and depth of thinking
  • Quality of analysis and reflection
  • Engagement with lecture/tutorial/workshopping content
  • Application of learning to your own writing
  • Completion of all parts of the weekly prompt
  • I'll go through logbook results during selected tutorials


Your active participation in peer workshopping is essential and forms part of your overall learning and development in this course. The in-person weekly reflection logbook requires you to show how workshopping is helping you improve your own writing. You will submit a longer version of this same draft as your final submission. Note: This assessment has a pass/fail hurdle.

Peer Workshopping Requirements

You will submit a draft of your creative work for peer workshopping early in the course (up to 1,000 words). In return, you will also read and workshop your peers’ drafts. This is a weekly requirement and an important part of developing your craft.

The set reading list for this course is intentionally short to ensure you have sufficient time each week to:

  • Read your peers’ work carefully
  • Provide thoughtful, constructive feedback
  • Apply feedback you receive to your own revisions


If you have an SAPD that allows changes to this assessment, please contact me directly at the start of semester.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person, weekly. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit handwritten logbook entry to tutor during the tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Read the excerpt provided, then identify one craft technique from the list that is used in the excerpt. Then respond to the five questions below ensuring you remain within the indicated word limits. Total word count is between 800-1000 words. Do not go over or under this word count range.

Question 1 – Define the element of craft you’ve chosen (approx. 50 words)

Question 2 – Analyse how the chosen craft element functions in the excerpt. What effect did the author achieve, and why did it work? (Approx. 500 words)

Question 3 – Explain how studying this craft example can inform your own creative practice. (Approx. 100 words)

Question 4 –Write an original paragraph to demonstrate how you have learned to use this craft element in your own writing. (Approx. 250 words)

Question 5 – Write a short original writing exercise which teaches someone how to learn this craft element. (Approx. 100 words)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
AI-use must be acknowledged and referenced. Please add your AI statement to the cover sheet as per previous assessments. This should include the AI chart and your statement (and references if relevant).

Task description

Write an opening of a novel, in the genre of the student's choice, 1800-2000 words. Within this wordcount you must:

* Define the genre conventions in a separate introductory paragraph (keep it brief/bullet points are fine)

* finish the scene

* include an outline of the remaining scenes in the chapter (1-2 lines per scene)

* remain within the allowable word count range (this may require you to tighten what you have written)

* this must be the final draft of the work started in Week 1 (you cannot submit a different story with different characters/plot)


Your opening scenes should do the following:

Conflict

o It must have some foreshadowing or link to the broader plot.

o It must have a ‘hook’ that leads into the next chapter/scene.

Character

o It must establish the character’s motivation.

o It must involve dialogue between at least two ‘in-scene’ characters at some point

Context/Setting

o It must have a concrete setting that is introduced and explored in some way.

o The setting must in some way be researched or designed.

Structure

o It must have at least two scenes.

o The ending of the chapter should coincide with the ending of submitted sample.


Format:

* Double spaced

* In a 12 point font (preferably a serif font e.g. Times)

* Have margins of at least 2.5cm all around

* Indent the first line of every paragraph

* Use only one hard return (enter key) between paragraphs

* If you are in doubt, look at a published book and lay out just like that, but double spaced

* Incorrect layout will lose you marks on presentation

*Going over or under the word count range will gain a penalty from the rubric for not following guidelines


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
